_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
ConAgra International Fertilizer
Hastings, NE.

I.    The Facility Policy:

The Facility owner, management, and employees of ConAgra International Fertilizer are 
committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Local 
responders are encouraged to visit the Facility to gain first hand knowledge of the site. 
Employees are required to hold monthly safety meeting and include sections of the 
management plan in those meetings. The Facility incorporates an internal written emergency 
contingency plan at the location.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is 
prepared to work with local fire departments, and authorities to mitigate any release, and 
to minimize the impact of a release on the population and environment.

II.   Facility Information:

The primary activity of the Facility is to provide agricultural fertilizer for the farming 
industry in the area.  Part of the fertilizer comes in the form of Anhydrous Ammonia, 
here after referred to as ammonia.  Ammonia is received, store, and used for production 
of  liquid fertilizer solutions. Ammonia is an important source of Nitrogen for agricultural 
crops.
 
The maximum quantity that can be stored in the stationary vessel is 170,000 pounds. 
There are times that rail cars of ammonia are received and unloaded as the product is 
produced.  It is not a practice to hold the car(s) any longer than necessary. The typical                                                    method of receiving ammonia is by truck transport containing 40,000 pounds. The process                                                      is considered a batch process and operates from time to time.

III.  Accidental Release Prevention:
   
The Facility takes guidance from material published by the American National Standards           
Institute "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" 
K61.1, and Compressed Gas Association CGA G-2.  The Fa

cility also has a Process 
Safety  Program that dovetails the RMP. The Facility tries to minimize the amount of 
ammonia held or stored at the facility through management judgment. The Facility 
continues to review and look for means to improve operating and Best management 
Practices for increase safety. The Facility is regulated by State ammonia regulations.

IV. The Five Year Accident History:
       
There have been no accidental releases of ammonia related to the operation of this facility 
in the past five years.  There have been no deaths, injuries, or significant property damage 
at the Facility.  To the best of our knowledge, no off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, 
sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage has occurred due to the 
operation of this facility.





Bibliography / References:
Technical Inc. prepared for NIOSH, HAZOP of  "Anhydrous Ammonia Use in 
Agricultural" 1991.

Clements Associates, Inc., Fairfax, VA;  "Health Effects for Ammonia, prepared for The 
Fertilizer Institute.

U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  "Chemical Emergency Preparedness and 
Prevention Advisory ? Ammonia", September 1991 Oswer 91-008.2, Series 8; No.2.

Ecology and Environment, Inc.,  "Generic Hazard Assessment and Off-site 
Consequences Analysis Kern and Kings Counties"' prepared for California Fertilizer 
Assoc. October 1990

American National Standard Institute, Inc., "American National Standard Safety 
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia"  (K-61.1) March 
1989
